excerpts.value: Keep up your heart , darling ! there are better days behind the clouds : keep up your heart she said cheerfully ; and assuring her sister that she should not be long away , she started off with her bundle under her arm to be at her destination before the shop closed for the evening .Nellie had to traverse innumerable narrow , reeking streets before she reached the slopshop .slopshop .

Sometimes half a dozen neighbours Avould pop in during the day to exchange gossip with Nellie Jefferson ; but as luck would have it , on this particular Monday not a creature came near the house .The poor girl , in the bitterness bitterness of her heart , imagined that they had scented afar off the taint that had come upon their name .The morning was very long , for it was hard to sit down to sew with such a sorroAvful spirit ; but it had become more necessary now than ever .

Geoffry , nothing loath , reseated himself , as Nellie entered Avith a pile of buttered toast and some hot muffins .Tliere was a fragrant odour issuing from the kitchen of broiled ham , which presently made its appearance , temptingly temptingly overlaid Avith poached eggs .Jefferson smiled his satisfaction at his useful daughter , and nodded approvingly at Geoffry , as the Avhole party drew round the table to tea .

In autumn , when the branches were less luxuriantly clothed , the beams pierced through , and made a checquered , wavering network of light on the grass below .In spring - time , these glades were bright with the yelloAv daffodils , and wild , white anemone , and the purple hyacinth , of heavy , sickly fragrance .Later in the year , the tall foxglovTe rose up from the tufted mounds , and the ragged - robin grew richly about the roots of many a patriarch of the 167 ROUSER .

There was a glowing suu that gave a reminder of summer days ; the crisp brown leaves from the trees in Old Court Yard had fallen , many of them , over the wall , and lay in a bed on the pavement .Nellie ' s feet lingered amongst them ; she liked their rust - Â © Â © ? ling sound and earthy smell .I knoAv not what thoughts of the country life she might have led , came across her as she crushed them under her lagging tread ; but her heart bounded wildly in her breast , and she uttered a stifled cry .

61 THE FALL OF THE LEAF .red , and yellow , and broAvn , and the east winds blew sharply amongst the gables and chimneys , and the dead leaves went whirling and driving down the paths , and gave out a smell of decay as the foot crushed them .It Avas the last Aveek in October , and the visitors were all gone ; and , to Letty ' s no more were coming till Christmas .

Rouser got up , shook himself , seemed to reflect on the propriety of doing his duty cheerfully , attempted a Avag of the tail ( Avhich proved a very limp wag indeed ) , and then , with Letty ' s hand on his collar , they went to Mellow ' s quarters .Lor ' ! Miss Lettice ! you aren ' t surely a - going to bring that great big dog in here said cook , in dismay , eyeing the viands , which she was preparing for the spit , with an anxious air ; for Rouser * s glance had kindled , and his nose instantly scented the dulcet perfumes to which he was being introduced .Betsy was despatched to find a dish of cold meats in the larder , with which Rouser was plentifully regaled ; and then having bestowed bestowed a mark of his favour , in the shape of a lick , on Mrs Mellow , which elicited the exclamation â   Beast ! from that worthy , Lettice and her new companion decamped .

ing trees : altogether a pretty picture of a wealthy English home .Nearer the house , the gardens preserve the stiff French fashion in which they were originally laid out : terraces , terraces , with stone vases , urns , images , and flights of broad steps with flowery creepers covering the narrow , low , side walls ; alleys arched over with climbing plants , and making making a pleasant dusky shade in the hottest noon of summer ; great borders of scented floAvers , and fountains with their undraperied nymphs .Many of these things had been restored by Miss Talbot ' s father ; but everything had been done with a view to preserve the harmony of the whole : and with considerable success , it must be owned .

133 To be sure , ma ' am ! to be sure ! I quite agree with you â   exactly responded Meynell Meynell ; brightening up at the sound of his name from the dozy state into which he had fallen after supper , and coinciding Avith he knew not what .I often lie aAvake o ' nights , thinking of my said Goodhugh , after a pause , during wliich the whiffs of Aaron Lee ' s pipe and the whispered talk of the young folk became unpleasantly unpleasantly distinct for the latter .Ah ! Jem was a fine lad â   the very moral of his father .

The charms of morning in country places have had many celebrators ; the charms of morning in town but feAV .Yet even in the vicinity of Old Court there was a certain degree of freshness , in the earlier hours of the day : an absence of that reek and steam of human life , close crowded in narroAV dwellings , dwellings , that made noon heavy , and eveningnauseous .eveningnauseous .
words: in the vicinity of Old Court
